i'm guessing the rest of you use AWS session manager or something

text: tmux
I launch my process in the background, and I have a signal handler to ignore `SIGHUP` so I don’t have to remember to `disown` or run under `nohup` when I close the terminal like one minute later.

elements.text: I launch my process in the background, and I have a signal handler to ignore
so I don’t have to remember to
when I close the terminal like one minute later.

text: Is `sighup` needed for tmux? I get a bad feeling that flumine is hanging after i detach and close the console

elements.text: needed for tmux? I get a bad feeling that flumine is hanging after i detach and close the console

text: I don’t really understand what tmux has to do with it?

elements.text: really understand what tmux has to do with it?

text: But I’d expect yes.
tmux is just another layer in your terminal right, you’re still connecting to a remote host via some protocol like ssh?

elements.text: tmux is just another layer in your terminal right,
still connecting to a remote host via some protocol like ssh?

text: No you don’t need it for tmux
ok thanks all

Hi folks - is there a standard way (or an existing library) to parse betfair stream data from files to build the state of the orderbook at a point in time?

I want to eyeball a few things now after several months of good data harvesting… thanks

elements.text:
Hi folks - is there a standard way (or an existing library) to parse betfair stream data from files to build the state of the orderbook at a point in time?

I want to eyeball a few things now after several months of good data harvesting… thanks

text: Shameless plug but take a look at `betfairutil` and `betfairviz`

text: Won't you need to ssh into the server in order to execute "docker run..."?

text:
Fwiw I prefer using systemd to run stuff, rather than docker.
Using docker involves a lot of IT skills in order to build and set up the image.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
Fwiw I prefer using systemd to run stuff, rather than docker.
Using docker involves a lot of IT skills in order to build and set up the image.

text: I use a config file (json) and a simple serverless script picks it up, creates/starts instances if required and builds/runs containers as per the config. Haven’t used SSH in a few years

elements.text: I use a config file (json) and a simple serverless script picks it up, creates/starts instances if required and builds/runs containers as per the config.
used SSH in a few years

text: Infrastructure as Code should set you down the rabbit hole

elements.text: Infrastructure as Code should set you down the rabbit hole

text: :face_palm: If you’re doing `docker run` from a terminal via ssh and haven’t learned how to spin up an image/server to start something on boot (hint: Dockerfile is a fundamental concept of Docker), what the hell is the rest of your code like? Come on. Basics. You don’t need to be a pro sys admin to nail simple stuff…
